urn:contentItem:5X1T-3D41-JB20-G45B-00000-00SL Green Realty Corp at Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Real Estate Conference - Final2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:36ZLexisNexis091019a12712013.713SL Green Realty Corp at Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch Global Real Estate Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Andrew W. Mathias

SL Green Realty Corp. - President & Director

* Matthew J. DiLiberto

SL Green Realty Corp. - CFO

* Steven M. Durels

SL Green Realty Corp. - Executive VP & Director of Leasing & Real Property

Conference Call Participants

* James Colin Feldman

BofAMerrill Lynch, Research Division - Director and Senior US Office and Industrial REIT Analyst

Presentation

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN, DIRECTOR AND SENIOR US OFFICE AND INDUSTRIAL REIT ANALYST, BOFAMERRILL LYNCH, RESEARCH DIVISION: Thank you for attending this conference. In this roundtable, President, Andrew Mathias; to his left, CFO, Matthew DiLiberto; and Executive Vice President, Director of Leasing & Real Property, Steve Durels; and Anastasia Verghis, Head of Investor Relations. So the spirit of these panels really is a larger meeting, so please feel free to chime in (inaudible). But if you have follow-up questions on anything you have, definitely chime in. We want to make sure (inaudible).

Questions and Answers

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: So I guess just starting out, frustrating performance in the stock over the last 12 months. I know you guys are taking steps to try to fix the problem, create value through buying back shares. Just -- when you guys come in the office every day, talk about the level of frustration and talk about the things you think you could do that -- to change things, or just kind of expand and pass it around.

ANDREW W. MATHIAS, PRESIDENT & DIRECTOR, SL GREEN REALTY CORP.: Well, I would say, we're first and foremost a real estate company, not a stock company. So the vast majority of our 300 people are focused on executing our business plan, which is running on all cylinders right now, on the leasing side, on the development side, on construction, and then on also obviously, the accounting and balance sheet side. So we sit in a New York City market that is very healthy for the most part with an upward revisions in jobs, private sector jobs for 2019, which I don't think -- we didn't expect, I don't think the city itself expected, a healthy investment sales market where we've seen a lot of transaction activity this year and a lot of different buyer groups emerging for assets like 540 Madison, retail assets like 711 Fifth Avenue, a very varied group of assets. And a leasing market, which continues to show a lot of strength in all the different sectors, particularly TAMI, which is getting a lot of the headlines but also financials, education, health care and government.

So we're operating in a very healthy market, and our job as managers is to keep our people focused on creating value and sort of executing SL Green's business as opposed to keeping their eye on the screen and judging themselves from the stock price, which we've been operating in a market now for about 4-plus years where the stock price has been completely divorced from our view of underlying asset value, and now it's in the markets prevailing view of asset value. So we're sticking to our strategy, executing it. We've communicated that clearly to investors, and we'll continue to take advantage of spot market. Real estate prices and buying in stock to the authorization where the Board is currently out, which is $2.5 billion of total program and potentially beyond [reversal signal].

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: So should have actually started with any message you wanted to pass along. I got a little excited, it's my first roundtable today. So with your prepared remarks, you wanted to get across and you did a good job answering (inaudible). Anything you wanted to say (inaudible).

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: No. I mean that I think wanted to just give an overview of the market -- investment sales market, the leasing market. And the one thing I didn't touch on is our development pipeline where we're really focusing a lot of our time, attention and capital. Obviously, One Vanderbilt, steel will top out this month, curtain wall complete in December, and we're on track and ahead of schedule from our initial time line for TCL August of 2020. So we have turned over space in the bottom of the building to tenants who have begun their buildouts. And again, the doors will open next August.

On the heels of that, we have foundations well in process, of 185 Broadway just up the street here. On our first 70/30 affordable residential deal. Developments in full swing at 460 West 34th Street, which we just closed on in May. And we're deep, deep in planning on 1 Madison, where we'll be completely transforming that building after Crédit Suisse leaves at the end of 2020. So a lot of exciting plans and a lot of profitable action on the development side, I guess, was the other thing we wanted to communicate.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: I know it's the smallest of the parts that you mentioned, but what are your background of any -- what changes in with the rent control (inaudible) in underwriting the outlook?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: There is no change. They did exempt affordable New York from the changes they made in rent regulation. So we're still 30% affordable and 70% market rate without any type of rent restrictions. So the underwriting there is intact.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: And there's been a lot of press activity about the big leases roaming around the 34th Street area west side, both in new construction and new (inaudible) projects. Can you guys talk about leasing pipeline, just generally for New York but also that part of the market and just kind of help with (inaudible) what you're seeing across the submarket?

STEVEN M. DURELS, EXECUTIVE VP & DIRECTOR OF LEASING & REAL PROPERTY, SL GREEN REALTY CORP.: Well, start with the fact that from our perspective, we had probably one of the busiest summers from a leasing perspective that I can recall for many years. It was -- we've got a huge pipeline right now of almost 1 million square -- 1.4 million square feet with over 950,000 square feet of leases that are actually in the document negotiation as we sit here today. We've signed leases of over 1.1 million square feet against the year-end target of 1.5 million. So we feel comfortable that we'll achieve that goal and exceed it. And when you break it down by industry, what we're seeing, which I think is a reflection of what the overall marketing is experiencing, has been a big drive year-to-date from the FIRE sector, from financial and insurance in particular.

But what's in the pipeline right now is it -- are the TAMI tenants. We've said to many investors on conversations over the past several months that we had a -- we did a tour of the West Coast at the beginning of the year. And the feedback that we had from that was that every large tech tenant that we met with, every brand name that all of us would know communicated to us that they were coming into New York City in a very big way. And you're starting to see that, whether that's Google or Microsoft or Facebook or some of the other big names are out there, all these guys are turning their attention to the East Coast because it's gotten too pricey on the West Coast. The housing is too pricey, the competition for talent is too difficult. And what we heard from them very clearly was East Coast is our new focus. We're not coming in a small way, we're coming in a big way. It's no longer about these little boutique buildings down in Chelsea where we think 10,000 square feet and make it work because it's cool. They're going to need big buildings with big infrastructure, and you're seeing that borne out by some of the big deals that are in the market right now. Facebook's negotiating a big lease over in Hudson Yards. We heard the other day that they put another proposal out in the market for another 700,000 square feet in addition to that.

And then there are other names that I can't really rattle off because we're under nondisclosure agreements with some of these guys. But they were all knocking on our door as well, taking a look at 1 Madison Avenue. We're actively trading paper with a couple of tenants of size for that building. No promises as to whether we sign a deal in the near term, but I think it's a good barometer of as we sit here in 2019 for a project that doesn't deliver until the third quarter of 2023, that we are engaged with tenants who need big footprints, and 1 Madison is a unique product in the right part of town and has all the bells and whistles that these guys are looking for.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: So it's -- and when I think about that a lot, I mean you guys have -- I mean it's a great deal in a great location but there's not 1 million square foot potential expansion next door when one of these big tech tenants decide that they need the next building. And I assume that's the attraction of having the leasing in the Hudson Yards and in the [west sides]. It's a long pipe. As much as we say the drag on New York City is the pipeline, the benefit to attract I think a lot of these tenants is the potential pipeline of new product with good infrastructure that we're talking about.

STEVEN M. DURELS: Well, I think what you've seen -- what Hudson Yards has proven to all of us is that tenants will sacrifice location for the benefits of new construction or heavily redeveloped buildings. And you've seen that's where the disproportionate amount of the leasing is taking place for large blocks of space this year. We saw it last year as well. But Hudson Yards as a new neighborhood is driven not by the convenience of the neighborhood and not by the cool factor of the neighborhood; there was nothing there to begin with. It's because that's where the product was. And these tenants who need large blocks of space, they want the benefits in new construction. That's not just infrastructure, that's high ceilings and big windows and natural daylight and [concrete] floors and all -- everything else that supports the operation of their business.

So when you look at a building like 1 Madison Avenue, we have that. We're 1.4 million square feet at the end of the day. We're in a neighborhood that has other buildings surrounding it. But we have, like, new construction of the building. One Vanderbilt has proven the thesis as well, right? It's -- so when everybody had these headlines of the world is shifted to the West side, that was a false statement. That's because the product was there. They came back to Midtown proper with One Vanderbilt Avenue. As we sit here today, 59% leased. They're still a year away from completing the building, where tenants didn't want or weren't prepared to sacrifice location and weren't prepared to pay the rents necessary to be in Midtown proper in the convenience of great transportation.

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: I would also say, if you look at Google and their "campus", which is actually Chelsea Market and then all the way down to St. John's terminal, tenants are willing to stretch the definition of directly adjacent expansion space to be on subway lines or quickly commutable back and forth. So I don't think 1 Madison will be constrained at all by the surrounding product. We own 11 Madison Avenue just 1 block north, which has a significant amount of square footage, albeit all leased. And I think tenants will see expansion possibilities in the future in that neighborhood.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: (inaudible) [had an interesting lunch with R C Stacum] yesterday. I didn't realize, but [she had] said both Google and Disney, a big part of their decision go to that area was for the cable, the [thing] of the dark fiber, which I did not know. So that's -- I assume move more companies to go down there to get more access to that?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: Yes, I mean, I think that fiber runs all on that spine. So...

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: But as you guys think about the next (inaudible) in New York City and where things are going, and we've got the Midtown East on the plan. There's a pretty good article about a week ago, (inaudible) that were saying how it's working. I assume you do like, as you guys think about planning the portfolio, you want to have more aggregated locations where you can -- like I mean BofA right now is a good case in point. They've got our building right across the street. They're taking more space and it's walkable. So I agree with you. You can be there by subway. But it just seems like that's where everyone is heading. Do you think that as we look at SL Green in the future that's -- the direction the company will be heading and the portfolio can be heading, and you just kind of pick your nodes in all neighborhoods?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: Well, I guess, I mean, we are neighborhood focused for sure on Grand Central. As far as Midtown East rezoning is concerned, we don't have any other buildings right now where the occupancy profile kind of lines up for our redevelopment that would be economically viable even with the upzoning. So we don't expect to see a lot of new supply coming on in Midtown as a result of the rezoning because like a lot of owners are looking sort of the same economics we're looking at. One Vanderbilt was a special project with particular rezoning and a bunch of other ancillary businesses that kind of make that project viable, but I don't see demolishing a lot of our other existing inventory.

But we are geographically focused for sure, and with One Vanderbilt, we've leased a tenant in One Vanderbilt. We've also taken space in other buildings we own in the area to support that front office operation. That's been a very successful strategy for us. So we'll continue to concentrate ownership in that area.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: Maybe can we just talk about what the demand pipeline actually looks like in full in Midtown, and then studying specifically One Vanderbilt. Any changes as your leasing projects approach year-end?

STEVEN M. DURELS: No, I think, as we sit here today, we have a high degree of confidence that we'll meet our target for the year. We're -- as I said earlier, we're 59% leased. We have other leases in negotiation. Hopefully, those close when they sign this year, that they'll put us over the goal line or at the goal line for the 65% target for the year. And we've got proposals on the table with another 4, 5 tenants. Everybody that's looking at the building today are financial service businesses. I mean we've done leasing to date with law firms, financial service and some public real estate firms. But everybody that's in the pipeline today are financial services. And we're trading paperworks at both the bottom of the building and in the penthouse of the building as well.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: What do you have left to lease this quarter?

STEVEN M. DURELS: It's spread around. The biggest chunk there is 2 base floors, 15 to 16 floors, that's about 90,000 square feet. And then we've got a smattering of floors in the midrise, and then we've got 8 of the 9 penthouse floors left.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: (inaudible)

STEVEN M. DURELS: They range anywhere between 140 in the base and then into mid-ish 200s for 1 or 2 floors at the very top. Most of it's in the 150 to 180 range.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: And then what are your latest thoughts on the observatory?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: Yes, plan's proceeding. The escalators are in the space. I mean it's spectacular physical space, and we continue to see big demand for the type of attractions we're going to offer directly connected to Grand Central, so we're very excited to bring it online. But everything's still proceeding according to plan.

STEVEN M. DURELS: I'll add to that because I took a group up the other day. And when Andrew says it's amazing physical space, that's -- he's understating it. It is an extraordinary experience to be on those floors with these super high ceilings and oversized windows and a view that allows you to look directly down onto Times Square and Bryant Park in the center of Manhattan. It's -- it really hits you in the gut, it's great, great observatory space.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: Do you guys still feel comfortable with your original NOI projection for the observatory?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: Yes.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: So when do you think we'll start to see a more detailed plan? Investor Day?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: I don't know if Investor Day, there's going to be much more to unveil. We haven't sort of -- we haven't hashed that out yet. But certainly, as we get into next year, there'll be more detailed plans and some early marketing.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: When do you think would go?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: What is our...

MATTHEW J. DILIBERTO, CFO, SL GREEN REALTY CORP.: It's probably the late -- a year after TCL. Late '21.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: Any questions from the room?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Just taking one step back to your original comments, Andrew, about the stock not aligned exactly with what you've delivered over the last 4 years. I guess just from a strategy-forward level, how do you think about that for -- I mean how long if that continues? Is it next year or the next few years? What are some of the thoughts there on how to close that?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: Well, I think the Board is pretty resolute in the fact that we can control what we can control and, obviously, can't control the stock price. So we have what we believe to be a very sound business strategy, a very conservative financial strategy only using proceeds from sales to delever and to buy back stock. And we feel like we've significantly improved the company and the balance sheet and really that the remaining holdings with the sales we've made to date. So we continue to view it as a market opportunity, I would say. And although we'd love to see shareholders rewarded with higher stock price, obviously, the dividend continues to be very healthy. And we view it more as a market opportunity or business opportunity, really unique business opportunity that's persisted rather than sort of a -- something that has to be addressed in some kind of emergency manner because we don't think we can control it.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: I think Marc commented at the Investor Day that the -- taking the company private, like just -- you can't do a deal of that size of taking the company private. Is there a threshold you guys think about that would be the right size of a deal and getting it done?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: I mean it's not something we're really measuring day-by-day. So I don't know the threshold size. But certainly, we're still of a scale that we think it would be -- it's a very large check to take the company private.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: On revisions (inaudible) today and how you think about the (inaudible)?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: Sure. We have a slide on that.

MATTHEW J. DILIBERTO: Yes, for those who have decks in front of you, we do have a new SG section towards the back and it actually lays out a time line for some of the new regulations. I mean really, I mean just...

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: It's on Page 44.

MATTHEW J. DILIBERTO: 44. So basically, through 2029 or beyond 2029, there hasn't been -- the rules haven't been established. So we're actually part of a group of (inaudible) parties involved in evaluating what happens after 2029. Between now and 2023, there is no impact at all. And then beyond that, we're essentially in compliance today. Long and short is if we didn't do anything to the portfolio today through 2029, it would cost us a few hundred thousand dollars. That's it.

We have been extraordinarily proactive, that's also highlighted through these slides, in making our portfolio sustainable and being at the leading edge of the green initiatives for probably 10 years. We have a group of 5 professionals under -- and taken each step, oversee that initiative, the vast majority of our portfolio is -- are already LEED certified or ENERGY STAR certified. We have our scores here across all of the most relevant sustainability grading scores, and we submit to virtually all of them. We have either tied or outright the best scores there. We've been ahead of this. I think the new regulations are probably much more onerous for those who have not been trying to upgrade and redevelop their portfolios and get ahead of this. They may be facing some more significant financial burden over the next 11, 12 years. But for us, we're looking more beyond 2029 and what the impact might be, and we are part of that conversation determining what the new rules will be.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: Any questions?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: One follow-up on the original conversation on the tech tenants that Jamie talked about on his panel this morning. One of the popular questions we get is just the health of the tech companies and if the recession does hit. And again, our panel this morning kind of highlighted low probability of recession to Steve Roth commenting no recession ever again. But how do you think -- I guess how do you -- when you're thinking about these tech firms first, obviously, big differences of the early 2000s. But can they continue to plow through even if there is a pullback in the economy and continue to lease?

STEVEN M. DURELS: Well, I think it's a different profile tech tenant that's in the market today than it was 5, 10, 15 years ago. It is by and large the ones that I'm referring to that are migrating from the West Coast to the East Coast of size. These are not startup businesses. These are well-established, big brand-name companies, highly profitable firms. And they're the top companies in the world. So that wasn't historically the tech industry in New York City. That's -- I think that's a big headline change for New York City over the past couple of years where when you see Google, right, Google came to New York City. We all take Google for granted today and say, of course, they're here. But when they first came to New York City, they had a satellite office. And then over the past 10 years, they've grown to be a gigantic force within the marketplace. And you're seeing all of their peer group doing the same thing.

So whether that's Facebook and Amazon, or East Coast firms like IBM and -- or Netflix, they're all big, well-established companies, not like we saw at prior years where they were small boutique startups funded by VC capital. That suggests -- I mean those firms are there, but they're not the drivers in the marketplace.

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: What we're hearing consistently is that the talent is in New York City and Boston, and that's where the people of these firms have to hire are locating themselves after engineering school, after college. So the companies feel like they have to be here, and they're going to spend what they have to spend in order to really scale up here. They have access to that talent because they can't access it in the West Coast and Silicon Valley any longer.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: Maybe just one follow-up from the -- our econ panel this morning. Our strategist was commenting on, again, a question of recessions and pullbacks that usually starts with corporations freezing, holding on decisions. And we just want to make sure we ask each company at the conference, have you seen any change in the last week, month, 2 months with these macro risks and trade rhetoric rising? Anything, any change in the last couple months from just a leasing standpoint rhetoric conversation?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: We haven't any kind of pullback or any kind of pause on negotiations based on trade headlines or otherwise. If anything, I think rates have been fueling growth and, obviously, the rates have trended down significantly. So that's made companies more apt to make capital decisions and commit for longer terms.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: Then maybe on Amazon. Do you think that they'll still wind up taking all the space they were looking for in Queens, but in Manhattan? How do you think that plays out?

STEVEN M. DURELS: I think it's to be seen. They're clearly growing in Manhattan. So whatever they were going to do in Queens, that requirements or some portion of that requirement is going to shift to Manhattan. Whether it's the same footprint or not, I couldn't tell you. But they're not shying away from being in Manhattan and they're clearly on a growth path.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: And maybe -- sorry, one last on the recession [we put out or recession read] reports and look to historical and never love to just look at historical point of view but office -- the office sector, where the data exists historically has been the most volatile. So I mean I asked you to come out with a view on what could be different. Unfortunately for office, we said probably not different. But if you have a view to, at the end of the day, agree or disagree?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: Leverage levels are much lower this time around, you would have to say. So...

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: Yes, we did consider that. But NOI standpoint, just from the nature of the business.

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: We have the longest -- among the longest or if not, the longest average lease term in the business here in New York and on our portfolio in particular. So we feel like we have a very solid credit portfolio with long lease terms that sort of ride through economic cycles, and we have a very conservative leverage profile. So that's supposed to lead to less volatility and recession. Obviously, you have market fluctuations that are -- capital flows that you can't really control, but we do feel like we're positioned very defensively at this point for any type of eventuality.

MATTHEW J. DILIBERTO: Yes. Just add to that, [Jeff], because you're referring to historical data. If you look at our historical same-store NOI growth for 20 years, we have the highest average of any of the office REITs over that duration. Being in New York provides us an advantage along with the long lease terms that Andrew highlighted. Our occupancy has never been below 94%, so we keep it full. And the leases in New York provide protections, right? We are insulated against expense increases and the leases generally provide for rent escalations over time.

So even in a downturn, if you have a full portfolio with low lease roll and leases that provide the expense protection and rent growth, you can even maintain positive same-store NOI growth in a recessionary environment, and that's what we've shown. So 4%, 20-year average same-store NOI growth is what we enjoy, and that's in part as a result as being so concentrated in New York and the leases that we have here.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: Just a remark about this morning talking about just Wall Street job cuts, potentially job cuts coming and they talk about Goldman (inaudible) they talk about overall it's been a very slow year for (inaudible). Steve, as you think about the footprint of the investment -- of the big banks, would you see material job cuts out of New York City hiding the impacts of [volume] in terms of how the [condos] footprints look today and how much excess capacity you think they have?

STEVEN M. DURELS: Well, I don't hear that a lot of them are sitting on extraordinary amount of excess space the way we've talked about in prior cycles where there was a lot of shadow space. Certainly, if there are job cuts, then that'll obviously have a dampening effect on the leasing environment. But one of the silver linings of densification for these, whether it's financial firms or all industries that have migrated to more open plan work environments and densified their occupancy of their employees, it becomes increasingly harder for those types of businesses to divide their spaces and take some of that space to the sublease market, as opposed to when there is various departments and they can sort of segregate them off and say, okay, I'm going to lease half that floor or this is part of my space. Now a lot of businesses are just kind of crunched into one envelope of space. And it's tougher for them to take space to the sublease market. So we don't have a lot of competition on the direct space competing in a sublease space.

But having said that, I don't hear a lot of firms sitting on excess space, just the (inaudible) that came out over the last recession how people manage their real estate. People -- firms are leasing space as they need it as opposed to leasing space proactively warehousing it and hoping that they grow into it. I just don't see that as much as we did in prior cycles.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: And Matt, how do you think about your current leverage and any appetite on taking them lower for any kind of (inaudible)?

MATTHEW J. DILIBERTO: No appetite to take it lower. We're 44% LTV, and that's where we expect to stay. I know there's a lot of people who want to use debt-to-EBITDA. And I've kept my debt-to-EBITDA soapbox up in the conference room. Anastasia said don't bring it down and kill too much time. But look, when we are buying back stock, which is debt-to-EBITDA negative and doing development that is debt-to-EBITDA detrimental, the exercise of maintaining leverage neutrality in an LTV basis while executing those things is challenging enough. That is our target. That's our goal, is to maintain leverage neutrality at LTVs that are by private market standards, too low, by public market standards, I think, prudent. And we're going to continue to execute the asset sale share buyback program and the redevelopment projects with that thought in mind.

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: We've seen the private markets continue to push up the amount of leverage they're using on acquisitions, given the rate environment. I think some of the bids we're entertaining on our own assets where we see institutional capital with a higher tolerance for 65% to 70% leverage financing themselves quite a bit more than what used to be sort of the core buyers, who are more in the 55% to 60% range are now pushing up and using more leverage, taking advantage of low rates, I would say, either make their returns or to -- depending on how you look at it, to increase their returns.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: And then, I guess, heading into (inaudible). Just as we think about -- there are a lot of -- there are moving pieces to your same-store this year with 1515 Broadway and there are some moving pieces next year, end of next year with 625. Can you just talk about the building blocks of the same-store or even earnings in '20 on some of the big chunks that you've given an indication about?

MATTHEW J. DILIBERTO: It's approaching year. It's not December yet though, right, Jamie? Next thing you know, we'll be answering your question. So look, we're going to come out in December with our 2020 guidance. I think the -- what we're going to be highlighting, and I think it's this -- is the growth even beyond 2020. That's what I think people need start to focus on is we'll be getting a lot of attention around whether that's Polo vacating or what's going to happen when we take 1 Madison offline. The sooner the better that we get CS out of the way and we can commence the redevelopment.

This is all staging for growth in -- over the next 5 years, not the next 1. So we'll go through December, the building blocks, the things that are coming online nearer term, like 609 Fifth, where PUMA just opened last month. If you haven't been over there, go check it out. It's pretty spectacular. And the office space should come online middle of next year. One Vanderbilt to start to come on late next year, but we're staging the company right now for the next 5 years, not just the next 1, One Vanderbilt, 1 Madison, 185, all the projects that Andrew highlighted.

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: And certainly, at the investor conference, the focus will be on illuminating sort of that NOI bridge over the next 3 to 5 years.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: (inaudible)

MATTHEW J. DILIBERTO: I don't know total square foot, but we have 2 installations with that. So we have 609 Fifth where they have about 150,000 square feet or so. That's their co-working space. They're building that out now. It should open middle of next year. And then we have their enterprise business at 2 Herald that's fully leased to Amazon currently.

STEVEN M. DURELS: We'll probably grow the footprint a little bit incrementally. But we put them in the context of our exposure to the co-working industry as a whole because we're very -- sort of to the earlier conversation about how we manage the portfolio on the risk perspective, it's not just the length of the leases but it's the credit profile. It's not having too much exposure on any one industry as well. So we are very conscientious about not having -- being overexposed in the co-working industry. We think they're valuable to have a part of our portfolio, but with a very modest exposure, in the single digits.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: Can you talk about market brand growth? Any thoughts on where we are in manufactured brands year-to-date or within maybe upsell market?

STEVEN M. DURELS: Well, my own view is that I think it's much as we said at the beginning of the year where rents have been growing modestly, 3% to 4%, we think net effectiveness have modestly been increasing as well as concessions have stabilized. So if concessions have stabilized and face rents are increasing, there's a net effective growth. We're seeing it in our portfolio. It's not enough to shout it from the top of the mountain, but it's certainly a positive.

And with all of the health of the overall economy, the strength of the job market, if you're -- have a macro view that things are going to continue to be on solid footing, with the increased demand particularly from the tech tenants, the fundamentals would tell you that's more material rent growth has to be off in the not-too-distant future. But I don't think we're at a point we're going to predict that as we sit here today.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: And then the D&PE book, can you just maybe talk about where you're trending versus your guidance? And any opportunities for you (inaudible) in the investments?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: Sure. I mean I think that market is extremely healthy and competitive. A lot of big deals getting done. And I'd say, we're participating in our fair share or probably less so than at prior times because of the capital focus on stock buyback. So we are, as we indicated at the beginning of the year, letting that book roll down a bit and taking some payoffs. Those payoffs are coming in as anticipated, if not a little bit ahead of schedule as borrowers take advantage of frothy refinancing conditions. So we continue to see that book rightsizing a bit as we continue to focus our capital on stock buyback. But we still want to maintain our market share and, obviously, participate in our fair share of deals, which we've done this year.

MATTHEW J. DILIBERTO: Book balance probably below our initial guidance by the end of the year.

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: We were $1 billion...

MATTHEW J. DILIBERTO: We said down 100; we'll be down by more. Yes. Probably between $1.8 billion, $1.9 billion.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: And do you see -- is there a structural change in the market that (inaudible) up again or it just happened to be lower rates or...

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: No, it's lower rates. I mean it's just lower rates. We're absolutely return investors and we're comparing it against what we view as an absolute return on our stock buyback program. So as rates have fallen and the markets -- debt markets have continued to stay very competitive, that breakeven to stock buyback is getting very close on a lot of deals. And we'd rather invest in our equity overall than invest in the debt book.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: Okay. Any other topics that you want to address? All right. So just to wrap up here. Our fire -- our rapid fire questions here. Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch's U.S. economists now estimate 1 of 3 chance in the recession on the next 12 months. Are you and your board discussing recession more during recent meetings, the same as earlier in the year, or not at all?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: The same as earlier in the year.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: With macro rates rising, are you seeing any signs of a slowdown or pullback from your tenants in the last couple of months?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: We have not seen any slowdown or pullback, and there's no talk of tariffs or other macro issues impacting our portfolio thus far.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: And then finally, which of the following sectors do you think can surprise expectations the most for being defensive in the next recession? Industrial, retail, office or residential?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: That's a loaded question.

MATTHEW J. DILIBERTO: Office.

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: Our first 3 top choices are office.

MATTHEW J. DILIBERTO: Office, office, office.

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: If the top 3 choices are industrial, retail and residential, what would you say?

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: Well, I don't know if would be a surprise. I would say industrial, but...

JAMES COLIN FELDMAN: All right. Great. Thank you all very much.

ANDREW W. MATHIAS: Thank you.

urn:contentItem:609S-H651-JCJY-G2DM-00000-00Slick Bezos and Zuckerberg will bat away Congressional scrutiny;Big tech bosses are set to be grilled by US Congress on anti-competitive behaviour on July 272020-07-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:36ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYVersion:2Slick Bezos and Zuckerberg will bat away Congressional scrutinyBig tech bosses are set to be grilled by US Congress on anti-competitive behaviour on July 27By Robin Pagnamenta

Big tech bosses are set to be grilled by US Congress on anti-competitive behaviour on July 27

It should have been Day Five of the Olympic Games in Japan: an opportunity for hundreds of millions of people to binge on athletic disciplines they have been only dimly aware of for the past four years.

But while we will have to wait another year now to enjoy competitions in artistic swimming, shot-put, hammer throwing and rhythmic gymnastics, at least on July 27 viewers around the world will have the opportunity to live-stream another rare spectacle: the bosses of the world's most powerful technology companies being grilled by the US Congress.

Grab the popcorn. The House Judiciary Antitrust Subcommittee's questioning of Amazon's Jeff Bezos, Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg, Google's Sundar Pichai and Apple's Tim Cook, is likely to make for good television.

It's unlikely, however, to achieve much in terms of safeguarding consumers or tackling anti-competitive behaviour.

That's because while politicians around the world have shown themselves eager to convene and host hearings of this kind, they have been feeble at using them to achieve anything useful beyond the kind of grandstanding and pulpit bullying at which they excel, especially in an election year.

In fairness, the panel has scored a coup by managing to persuade all four men to appear on the same day-especially Jeff Bezos, the world's richest man, who has never before submitted himself to this kind of scrutiny.

But the format-a single afternoon session of questioning probably via video conference rather than in person-and the hearing's vague title "Online Platforms and Market Power: Examining the Dominance of Amazon, Facebook, Google and Apple" aren't exactly a promising start.

Put together, these four companies have a combined market value of $4.8 trillion-about 70pc more than the $2.8 trillion annual GDP of the UK and well over double the market value of the entire FTSE 100.

They dominate vast swathes of the global economy-from smartphones to online advertising, cloud computing to e-commerce-and wield huge and growing influence over virtually every facet of our lives-from the way we buy goods and services to the way we access news and information to how we educate our children or care for the sick.

But they are also very different businesses which bear surprisingly little in common with each other.

Lumping them together into an amorphous mass labelled 'Big Tech' is an elementary mistake which has been made many times before. It risks losing precious focus in a highly time-compressed format, and it offers the executives themselves the opportunity to obfuscate and hide behind each other.

In truth, each one of these chief executives would probably deserve a week of forensic questioning on specific areas of their corporate activity.

But the high commissions charged to third party developers on Apple's app store is an entirely different issue to the market dominance of Amazon Web Services, its highly profitable cloud computing arm, or the stranglehold over digital advertising enjoyed by Google and Facebook, or the issues around data mining and privacy linked to the growing popularity of home voice assistants like Alexa.

Instead, well briefed by the world's most expensive lawyers and PR experts and with only about an hour each in the spotlight, it's probable that slick operators like Jeff Bezos and Tim Cook will ooze charm and bat away most questions with ease.

In the event of awkward or difficult moments they will probably opt to keep cool and play for time-always the best defence for live-streamed events of this kind where a good TV performance often turns more on style than substance.

Indeed, the real pressure will be on the panel members to use the time effectively and to show they are properly across the brief and capable of asking challenging questions.

In similar past hearings, it has sometimes been the lawmakers rather than those being questioned who have been put on the spot.

Remember when Mark Zuckerberg last appeared before a Congressional hearing in 2018, and some of the panellists were clearly ill-prepared?

"Senator, we run ads," Zuckerberg responded with a smirk, when 84-year-old Republican Senator Orrin Hatch from Utah, asked how Facebook could sustain a business model in which its services were free.

"I see. That's great," was Hatch's red-faced response.

Politicians around the world-including in the UK-have repeatedly shown themselves to be ill equipped to ask the kind of probing questions necessary to elicit valuable or insightful answers.

Like Britain's CMA, which recently published a final report from a year long review of digital markets which was as vague and ineffectual as it sounds, regulators and politicians need to learn that the very real competition concerns raised by these companies are difficult to compare and highly specific.

We need more detailed work on specific areas-not broad brush criticism of the entire industry.

Of course, there is always the chance the hearing could surprise with a revealing moment or an insightful exchange.

If the panellists fail, then-like athletes at the Olympic Games-it will be a squandered opportunity for them and for the rest of us.

In agreeing to appear this month, Bezos, Zuckerberg et al will have a powerful argument that they should not have to do so again for an extended period-probably three or four years.

urn:contentItem:5VF6-GXN1-JCF2-81X4-00000-00Slick shift: Philip Morris' future vision;Is Philip Morris' new "smoke-free" mission statement a radical reinvention of the tobacco company - or sheer hypocrisy? COO Jacek Olczak says matter-of-factly - it's a strategic no-brainer.2019-02-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:36ZLexisNexisTHE RAFFLES CONVERSATIONTop StoriesSlick shift: Philip Morris' future visionIs Philip Morris' new "smoke-free" mission statement a radical reinvention of the tobacco company - or sheer hypocrisy? COO Jacek Olczak says matter-of-factly - it's a strategic no-brainer.Claudia Chong , Slick shift: Philip Morris' future vision

THE world's biggest listed tobacco company has a vision - to completely stop selling cigarettes.

Philip Morris International, owner of six of the world's top 15 cigarette brands including Marlboro, has publicly declared that it wants to build a "smoke-free future" by replacing all cigarettes with e-cigarettes or heated tobacco products.

"A smoke-free future, if you think very broadly, is actually a response to what consumers would like to have," Jacek Olczak, Philip Morris' chief operating officer (COO), tells The Business Times. "Many consumers will tell you that they like the product. But nobody is happy to live with the consequences of consuming the product; they know smoking cigarettes is bad for health. The other aspect is that while they are using the product, they don't want to have a negative impact on the people around them."

Mr Olczak adds that many people would like to quit smoking but are unable to see it through.

To be sure, this struggle to quit and the heightened public awareness of the harmful effects of smoking aren't new. Philip Morris - and its Big Tobacco peers - have been the subject of restrictive legislation from governments and criticism from health organisations for years.

So why choose now to stub out what has, for decades, raked in tons of profit for the company? Well, Philip Morris reckons it has something better to offer consumers. Against the backdrop of a steady decline in global smoking rates, the company has been aggressively pushing out its heated tobacco product IQOS in more than 40 markets.

IQOS is a pen-like device that heats tobacco up to 350°C. Philip Morris claims that because the tobacco is heated and not burnt, the user is exposed to 90 per cent less toxicants than in cigarette smoke.

Since 2008, the company has invested more than US$4.5 billion into research and development for its "reduced-risk products". Sales for such products, including e-cigarettes, contributed 13.8 per cent of its total revenue in 2018. The number of heated tobacco units shipped rose 14.2 per cent to 41.4 billion, and Philip Morris has declared a target of 90 to 100 billion units by 2021.

In Mr Olczak's words, the company has had to make dramatic moves. "You know, 15 or 20 years ago, to say that we would develop a safer product was a very visionary statement because we didn't actually know how to address it," he claims.

"We thought maybe it's the filtration, maybe the quality of the tobacco, maybe the other aspects of the product which would have to change in order to come up with a product that has significantly less toxicants in the smoke. And somewhere along the way, we discovered that the real problem of smoking was coming from combustion."

Smokescreen

Not that the public has completely bought into Philip Morris' "smoke-free" vision declarations. The company's supposed pivot from Big Tobacco to Big Tech has come under strong scrutiny. Non-profit organisation Truth Initiative, for one, has lashed out at Philip Morris, pointing out that it continues to lobby against measures such as higher tobacco taxes and bans on tobacco advertising and sponsorship.

If Philip Morris is truly committed to a smoke-free future, it should actively support policies to reduce cigarette smoking, and "set an example for the tobacco industry by stopping all marketing of cigarettes", the tobacco-free advocacy group said. The company's smoke-free goal - while it continues to aggressively market cigarettes, especially in low- and middle-income countries - has also been described as "the height of hypocrisy".

As for its supposedly "reduced risk" products, critics point out that using e-cigarettes, while apparently less toxic, is really no less harmful: In fact, vaping delivers a lot more nicotine (the addictive chemical in tobacco) than smoking and so may lead to even greater nicotine addiction. And the rise of vaping - especially popular with youths in America and Europe - is killing tobacco companies, analysts say. Hence Philip Morris' slick "smoke-free" shift, it's been wryly noted.

The company certainly has its work cut out if it wants to convince the world of its new mission. Back in October, Mr Olczak was in town to attend a meeting of the World Business Council for Sustainable Development, a global CEO-led organisation.

As he sits down with BT for this meeting, the exhaustion shows in the lines on his face. Jet lag shook him awake at 3am, he explains.

Still, when Mr Olczak is told that the photographer will snap shots of him during the interview, he pulls a face of such mock horror the room bursts out in laughter.

Even after years of globe-trotting for Philip Morris, the senior executive does not take kindly to plane rides. But when you're with Philip Morris, you've just got to accept that flights are part of the job, he tells this writer.

The native Pole has been in the company for just over 25 years. Before he became COO in January 2018, Mr Olczak was chief financial officer for about five years. Back then, he held a discussion almost every week with investors to assure them that the change in business direction was a strategic one.

He says matter-of-factly: "It's a better business because it's difficult to make it a worse business if you are better satisfying your consumers."

Then he takes off like a bullet train: "You have more than a billion smokers worldwide, and Philip Morris has about 27 per cent of the international market excluding China and the US. Consumers like our brands, and like very much the product and the quality, and the taste that we provide to them in the product.

"But nobody was happy with the risk associated with smoking. So if now you can make a product which gives you the same experience, but you know that you're not inhaling 90 per cent of the bad stuff in the smoke, it's difficult for the consumer to be against it.

"So you have a product which has the market. You have the advantage of being the first mover. And because you come in with innovation, you're premiumising your portfolio. You know you're a large company and you operate at scale, so if you have the right innovation you can launch it as we did with our product, in 43 markets, with the infrastructure in place, and scale up the innovation. I demonstrated in the past that I am a very skilled manufacturer so I can ride the economies of scale in terms of the product cost pretty fast.

"If I add it all together, it shouldn't be a worse business than the past business."

Just last week, Philip Morris beat Wall Street estimates by about 7 per cent to post an earnings per share of US$1.25 for the 2018 fourth quarter, following a year when the company recorded two major dips in its share price.

Analysts were encouraged by better than expected IQOS market shares outside its key market of Japan, such as in Italy, Germany and Korea. But market share in Japan fell 0.3 percentage points to 15.2 per cent.

Still, Mr Olczak remains bullish on the prospects in the country. As this interview is taking place in Fairmont Singapore, IQOS 3 is having its global launch in Tokyo, promising to convert even more smokers to the alternative product.

It is the company's ability to talk to the consumers that makes Japan such an important market for Philip Morris, says Mr Olczak. According to a survey by the company, about 40 per cent of smokers are aware of the heat-not-burn category of tobacco products and the perks of switching from conventional cigarettes.

Over in the US, Philip Morris is waiting with bated breath as the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) pores over more than four million pages of the company's scientific evidence. Two applications were filed with the FDA - one, if approved, will allow IQOS to be commercialised in the US and the other, if granted, will let Philip Morris make reduced-risk claims on product packs and marketing materials.

Then there remains the task of getting more regulators over to their side. Singapore, for one, has banned e-cigarettes and heat-not-burn products, as has Hong Kong.

And the company's loudest critic, the World Health Organisation, remains stony-faced as ever. Even as Philip Morris tries to reinvent itself, taking its story to Davos at the World Economic Forum, where it called for a truce between "anti-tobacco lobbies" and the industry, the WHO is not budging.

Says Mr Olczak : "As you can imagine, WHO is the biggest opponent of Philip Morris - and I don't think quite rightly so. Because if they were to cool down their emotions, you would realise that actually what we're trying to achieve now is fully aligned with what WHO wants to achieve."

In WHO's view, tobacco companies have misled the public about the risks associated with tobacco use, including promoting alternative products "while being fully aware that those products were not less harmful to health".

Mr Olczak is himself a smoker who has been using IQOS for five years.

"When I ask my doctor during my annual health check-up what he sees in my body with regard to my exercise capacity, my lung capacity, my cholesterol, etc, my doctor would think that I had quit smoking, and that I am not using any products!" he exclaims.

And Philip Morris' smoke-free goal seems also to have added a spring in many employees' steps, as he tells it.

"I actually think the motivation in the company these days is actually presumably higher than when I was starting 25 years ago," says Mr Olczak. "You know, we're running the company in the most exciting times. Not that many companies or industries can disrupt themselves at the core."

As an industry veteran, he sometimes gets asked how to have a "fast" career. "And I say I have no clue. But I can tell you that if you're working in a place that is dynamic and exciting, and you have exciting objectives and strategies, 25 years is like this," he says, snapping his fingers.

In fact, it often feels like he just started at Philip Morris' finance department only a year ago, he says. Asked if he can recall his first day at work, he says without missing a beat: "Yeah, it was 15th of March, 1993. I remember. Because normally, you never change jobs in the middle of the month, right? You usually start on the first of the month. But for whatever reason, Philip Morris told me to start on the 15th of March, 1993."

Moments after he passed through the office doors, he was asked to go for a briefing on the management performance appraisal system.

"And I said, 'Wow, that's very interesting, already on day one they are telling me how they are going to assess my performance. Maybe I joined the wrong company'," he says with a laugh.

But it turned out that the organisation wanted to regularly discuss his career aspirations and help him grow. It made a good impression on him. "Very often you go to the company and they put you behind the desk and say 'Here is a stack of papers; you have to process these papers', and they pay you. That's it. They couldn't care less how you feel."

Another topic that gets Mr Olczak visibly energised is music.

"Personally, I don't like being surrounded by people who don't have personal interests. You have to have something," he says.

Mr Olczak has a music studio at home decked out with four guitars, a saxophone, a trumpet, a keyboard, drums, microphones and recording equipment. Business is business, he says, and there are good days and bad days.

"When you come back home after a bad day, and you go to the music room for 15 minutes and you take the guitar and play, you relax like there is no tomorrow."

Asked if there is anything about Philip Morris that few know about, Mr Olczak returns to its organisational culture.

People typically have their guard up the moment they are approached, say by a headhunter, to consider joining Philip Morris, he says. "A lot of people would tell you initially, 'Philip Morris? No tobacco, I'm not going to tobacco.'

"But when they take the leap to have a conversation with the company, and eventually join, they realise it's a completely different world," he claims. "You have a purpose - you want to address the problem of smoking. You have diversity, people can develop, people can grow in the company, and this is not a hierarchical place. It's a great place to work."

Right before the interview ends, he lets on that in fact a few other companies offered him a job back in 1993.

"But I've never regretted the day I joined Philip Morris."

JACEK OLCZAK

Chief Operating Officer
Philip Morris International

Born January 1965 in Lodz, Poland

EDUCATION

University of Lodz, Poland: MA in Economics

CAREER HIGHLIGHTS

1991: Manager, BDO Binder in London and Warsaw

1993: Manager, Finance and Administration, Philip Morris Polska

1995: Manager, Internal Controls, Philip Morris International (PMI) in Switzerland

1996 - 2004: Various positions in finance, sales and operations, Philip Morris Polska

2004: Managing Director, Poland & Baltic States, PMI

2006: MD, Germany & Austria, PMI

2009: President, European Union Region, PMI

2012: Chief Financial Officer, PMI

Since 2018: Chief Operating Officer, PMI

urn:contentItem:5W88-HBK1-JBKR-9186-00000-00Sliding TSX back in February territory2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:36ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B2Sliding TSX back in February territoryRoss MarowitsThe Canadian PressTORONTO

Canada's main stock index dipped to its lowest level since February to start the week on heightened trade concerns, despite gold prices hitting a three-month high.

"We're seeing that trade tensions and trade concerns continue to put an element of caution in the overall equity markets," says Craig Fehr, Canadian markets strategist for Edward Jones.

Chinese and Mexican trade fears haven't disappeared, but Nasdaq dipped into correction territory as the influential technology sector was hit on news that the U.S. Department of Justice might be exploring some antitrust probes affecting Facebook, Google parent Alphabet Inc.and Amazon. That drove down their shares by as much as 7.5 per cent.

"That's particularly relevant for the markets because it has been those big tech names that have led the momentum to the upside for much of this bull market," he said in an interview.

The S&;P/TSX composite index closed down 21.60 points to 16015.89, after dipping to an intraday low of 15960.03, the lowest level in 15 weeks.

"All in all, we're seeing a very modest down day in the Canadian markets. We're seeing a little bit more of pressure on the global market and the U.S. equity indexes."

In New York, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 4.74 points at 24819.78. The S&;P 500 index was down 7.61 points at 2744.45, while the Nasdaq composite was down 120.13 points at 7333.02.

While the technology hit pushed the sector's index down 2.66 per cent in Toronto on a 4.3 per cent drop by Shopify Inc., it accounts for a much smaller part of the market in Canada.

Health care fell 3.68 per cent and the key energy sector dropped 1.36 per cent on ongoing concerns about the impact of a slowing global economy on demand, particularly from China. This occurred despite Saudi Arabia indicating that OPEC would continue supply cuts to help raise prices.

The July crude contract was down 25 cents at $53.25 US per barrel and the July natural gas contract was down 5.1 cents at $2.40 US per mmBTU.

Enbridge Inc. fell 4.7 per cent after a Minnesota court said state regulators must conduct a further review for Enbridge Energy's plan to replace its deteriorating Line 3 crude oil pipeline because the project's environmental impact statement doesn't address the possibility of an oil spill into the Lake Superior watershed.

The Toronto market was led by materials, which gained three per cent as Eldorado Gold was up nearly 12 per cent.

The August gold contract was up $16.80 at $1,327.90 US an ounce and the July copper contract was up one penny at $2.65 US a pound.

The Canadian dollar traded at an average of 74.24 cents US, compared with an average of 73.93 cents US on Friday.

urn:contentItem:60MB-G9J1-JDJN-64NK-00000-00Slow Internet, expensive data, and the burden of sub-sea Internet cables in Africa2020-08-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:36ZLexisNexisSlow Internet, expensive data, and the burden of sub-sea Internet cables in Africa

We live in an age where the Internet is fast becoming an essential part of human existence. Even the United Nations (UN) agrees that it is more of a right than a luxury. However, in Africa, billions of people are either unreached, have low-quality Internet, or cannot afford it.

This can be linked to several systemic issues across the continent, but several stakeholders can agree that a first step would be to deepen Internet infrastructure. Subsea Internet cables from the likes of Seacom, Glo, MTN, MainOne, and a host of others are the major backbone of such a move.

In May 2020, Facebook announced that it was planning to build a 37,000km subsea Internet cable worth $1 billion. While this seems like good news, theres just one small thing; from 2000 to date, at least 19 submarine Internet cables have been connected to Africa.

What are subsea Internet cables?

Subsea cables carry telecommunication signals across the continents of the world, connecting countries to international Internet exchanges.

The subsea cables are like the fibre cables laid on the land except that they have other materials protecting them as they have to stay underwater for life/long time, Simon* a top telecom executive explains.

Why are subsea Internet cables important?

Subsea cables help users access the Internet at high speeds. Your service provider connects to one or more of these cables which, in turn, offer you access to the Internet.

Subsea cables deliver Internet capacity and reliability and underpin the further growth of 4G, 5G, and fixed broadband access for countries, says Ifeanyi Akosionu, Business Director, Technology, Media and Telecoms (TMT) for Verrakki.

Damage to these cables can cause network disruptions, and you will either have significantly lower connectivity speeds or your network will be offline.

How does the value get to the user?

As Simon explains, service providers buy access to these cables at wholesale prices, and in turn, they retail it to end-users. Usually, the subsea cables connected to other continents give you access to their content.

However, the rise of local Internet exchanges a physical location where content providers and Internet service providers connect has made sure your requests for content do not go overseas.

Will more subsea cables bring faster Internet?

Having just subsea cables does not translate to faster Internet capacity. Service providers might only have to pay less to connect due to increased competition. Ideally, this should reduce the cost of data for end-users, but this is not always the case.

According to Akosionu, ample international capacity is good if countries have the required infrastructure to leverage. This will be through networks that take the capacity at the countrys borders to every state and town.

Akosionus statement points out the gap between Internet cable capacity at Africas borders and its states and towns. On closer inspection, this gap is massive.

According to data from Many Possibilities, the West and East African coasts each have cables with Internet capacity of at least 100 Tbps. By the end of 2021, the number could double.

In comparison, according to 2019 data from cable.co.uk, apart from Madagascar, no African country has an average Internet speed of up to 10 Mbps. Madagascar enjoys the benefits of a submarine cable that gives it an average of 22 Mbps, which is why it has a global ranking of 33.

However, other African countries are not so lucky. To reflect the gap in numbers, out of an available 100 million Mbps (100 Tbps) on the East and West coasts, African countries use just 10 Mbps on average.

Most of these countries rely on wireless 2G/3G networks, while a few have access to 4G networks that are usually slower than global standards.

While major cities like Lagos, Nairobi, and Cape Town can boast of decent network speeds, rural areas are either still unreached or underserved.

Funke Opeke, CEO of MainOne cable company, reveals that ten years after its launch, the MainOne cable (10 terabits) only operates at 10% capacity.

The importance of the last mile

Going past the sea level, for Africa to reap the full benefits of its Internet capacities, there have to be significant investments in fibre optic cables to reach the last mile.

Akosionu states that historically, base transceiver stations (telecom masts) achieved connections with the coaxial cables, but recent innovations have incorporated fibre optic cable connections using fibre-to-the-antenna (FTTA) technology.

According to him, as more people get connected to the Internet, and with 5G on the horizon, the case for such fibre network connections becomes stronger.

However, for most African countries, Internet infrastructure remains a big problem. This is usually the result of unfriendly business terrains, dominant monopolies, or multi-layered regulatory hurdles.

The result? Several locations still dont have access to the Internet, and for several others, the quality is subpar.

The possible threat of big tech

With the likes of Facebook planning to build a subsea Internet cable to add 180 Tbps to Africas current capacity, one has to ask where it will all fit in?

A report by Analysys Mason named THE IMPACT OF FACEBOOKS CONNECTIVITY INITIATIVES IN SUB-SAHARAN AFRICA(PDF) stated that Facebooks initiatives would generate up to $50 billion for Africa.

However, it is not clear how much Facebook is investing to deepen Internet infrastructure to the last mile.

Akosionu states that moves by the likes of Google and Facebook are the result of large volumes of data traffic on their platforms. For him, these deployments aim to hedge against insufficient cable capacity at agreeable commercial rates and provide route diversity, amongst other factors.

Akosionu affirms that the gap between terrestrial fibre networks and Internet cables needs to be closed for Africans to enjoy improved Internet at reduced costs.

Opeke further asks why Facebook is adding to an existing glut and not making use of what exists to deepen terrestrial infrastructure in Africa?

We have hundreds of terabits offshore, but we struggle to get one terabit around Nigeria, she explains.

Opeke points to the fact that over-the-top services offered by tech giants have slowly eroded telcos voice revenues over the years.

Despite the supposed growth in data traffic, voice has remained the cash cow and declines in voice revenues have not been offset by growth in data revenues.

If the profit margins of telcos become gradually eroded, what happens to them? Given the presence of Google or Facebook, what happens if they lose the incentive to build last-mile infrastructure?

Though Facebook is looking to partner with telcos, it is not clear how telcos will benefit considering the operational and regulatory hurdles they will have to face while deploying these infrastructures.

Barring a few states in Nigeria, for example, high fees are charged before telcos are granted permission to lay fibre-optic cables. Until recently, Telkom SA in South Africa enjoyed a monopoly on broadband.

Apparently, a lot of work needs to be done to connect Africa to the Internet at affordable rates for its citizens. It would, therefore, be interesting to see how big techs Interest in Africa plays out. 2020 Global Data Point.
